_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) as a representative of the UK overseas, plays a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government. 

The UK is one of eight founding members of the Open Government Partnership (OGP), an initiative now signed by over 70 countries around the world. However there is still much to do to realise the vision set out by the pillars of the partnership.

In this module we are going to explore...

  • The pillars of an open government
  • The role of open data in an open government
  • Moving to an 'open by default' agenda
  • The role of the FCO in supporting open governments
displayTitle: Openness and transparency in the FCO
title: Openness and transparency in the FCO

body: The UK is one of eight founding members of the Open Government Partnership (OGP), an initiative set up in 2011 and now signed by over 70 countries around the world. The OGP is an international platform for reformers committed to making their governments more open, accountable and responsive to citizens.
displayTitle: The pillars of an open government
title: The pillars of an open government
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body:
Transparency of information is the foundation of accountability in public services and open government.

Francis Maude, former minister for the Cabinet Office with responsibility for public transparency and open data said: "Transparency shines a light on underperformance and inefficiencies in public services. It allows citizens and the media to hold governments to account, strengthening civil society and building more open societies."

All government departments have committed to proactively publish a number of datasets openly, a commitment ratified by a letter from the prime minister in December 2017.

_items.title: Participation
_items.body:
Participation is about creating and using channels to solicit public feedback; and deepening public participation in developing, monitoring and evaluating government activities.

While Freedom of Information (FOI) provides a channel for the public to request information from public authorities, pro-active publication of open data has the potential to deliver much wider benefits and encourage better public engagement.

For example, in Mexico, Factico has developed mobile applications which enable citizens to report corruption, failures in public services and antisocial behaviour.

_items.title: Anti-corruption
_items.body:
Anti-corruption involves strengthening the rule of law and ensuring transparency in the management of public finances. It means establishing legal frameworks and taking measures to identify and prevent corruption. These include commitments to: publish information on the income and assets of high ranking public officials; expose corrupt bidders; implement open contracting data standards; recover stolen assets; and protect whistleblowers.

Increasingly, countries are taking steps to publish ‘beneficial ownership’ data - that is, information about who really owns and controls companies. This is important for exposing corruption, fraud, organised crime and tax evasion. 

Anti-corruption efforts are not just important in the UK but for any country that the UK chooses to do business with. 

Read more about the Global Declaration Against Corruption.

_items.title: Technological innovation
_items.body:
Technology has had a profound effect on all aspects of our lives. It has changed the way governments deliver services and engage with citizens. 

As a result citizens now expect to be able to engage through advanced digital platforms that deliver end-to-end services across government departments, from applying for benefits and passports, to paying parking fines and getting information on waste collection.

Governments have a key role to play in both delivering and enabling others to build digital services and technological innovation.

body:
'Open by default' is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed. This principle is at the heart of an open government and the FCO is committed to it.

This represents a complete mind change for many who currently take a demand-led approach to the publication of open data.

'Open by default' is the first principle of the G8 Open Data Charter and the international Open Data Charter. 

The Canadian government is piloting an 'open by default' approach to releasing public sector information in four of its departments. The pilot promotes the proactive release of scientific and cultural research data which supports government transparency and accountability.
displayTitle: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda
title: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda

body:
At the heart of open government is open data. Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It must be free from restrictions and openly licensed. 

Explore how open data can help deliver all four pillars of an open government.
displayTitle: The role of open data in an open government
title: The role of open data in an open government
instruction: Click on the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body:
Traditionally transparency has been the sole purpose of the Freedom of Information act (FOI). 

While open data will not remove the need for FOI channels, it can both reduce the number of FOI requests and streamline to response to others. 

In Carlisle, publication of real-time business rates has reduced the number of FOI requests, saving the council up to £15,000 annually. (Read the report here [PDF]: Local Government Open Data Breakthrough Projects Evaluation Report 2014/15).

In 2009–2010 FOI requests were estimated to cost the Greater Manchester public bodies over £4M a year. At the same time over 600 public officials a day were unable to find data they required for their jobs – costing over £8.5 million a year. DataGM was created to release and bring together as much data as possible, in one place, solving both problems. (Read more here in the Open Knowledge blog: Greater Manchester – Open Data City)

_items.title: Citizen participation
_items.body:
Open data allows citizens to see inside the workings of government, to monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account and participate in decision making.

The Linida initiative, Indonesia, provides a platform that local people use to engage with decision makers to negotiate, shape the development agenda and improve public services.

The Participatory Monitoring Maputo platform, Mozambique informs citizens about the need for proper waste removal and progress on waste removal, and aims to empower them to request services from the government through the use of a mobile app.

_items.title: Anti-corruption and fraud
_items.body:
In 2016 the UK became the first country in the world to collect and publish, in a structured format, information about who controls and benefits from companies. Read more about the world’s first public national beneficial ownership register here. 

Another way the UK government is tackling fraud – and the perception of fraud – is by publishing open data on government grant spending. In October 2017, the government introduced a platform allowing departments to share information on £100 billion worth of grants data from across government departments using a standard format developed by the 360Giving initiative.

Making contracting and procurement more transparent can also have big impact. For example Paraguay is using open contracting to improve spending on education. Information about education contracts unearthed a wider spending scandal that triggered a formal investigation, citizen pressure and reform of school spending.

_items.title: Technological innovation
_items.body:
Open data can help deliver new services to the public while driving efficiencies in the delivery of current public services.

Singapore is using open transport data and analytics to improve the commuting travel experience. Arrival times of buses are tracked using sensors installed in over 5,000 vehicles, to manage overcrowding and waiting times.

This data is then made available to the public and third party developers, who can put them to good use in creating people-centric transport solutions such as apps that help wheelchair users find accessible routes.

body:
The FCO is committed to open data. The department has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and its Open Data Strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets including those related to aid, consular services and spending.

The FCO currently makes use of both open and shared datasets for its internal activities, however challenges still exist in realising the benefits of a strong data strategy within the department.

This module looks at:

  • Data as a raw material
  • The benefits of data in the FCO
  • Supporting the FCO Open Data Strategy
  • Dealing with sensitive data
displayTitle: The role of data in the FCO
title: The role of data in the FCO

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
The FCO currently makes use of both open and shared datasets for its internal activities, however, challenges still exist in realising the benefits of a strong data strategy within the department.

Knowing what your commitments are as well as how to deal with sensitive data will help maximise the benefit of all types of data both internally and externally.

In the next module we look more at the practical steps to get started with publishing sustainable open data.
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body: An up-to-date inventory of data can help the FCO to:
displayTitle: Supporting the FCO open data strategy
title: Q: Supporting the FCO open data strategy
instruction: Select three answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Inform people about what types of data they can access from the FCO
Manage and organise your data assets
Assist in compliance with the new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requirements
Lower the responsibility of data owners
Decrease the number of FOI requests

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

An up-to-date inventory of data can help the FCO to: 

  • Inform people about what types of data they can access from the FCO
  • Manage and organise your data assets
  • Comply with new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requirements around maintaining records of personal data and processing activities

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An up-to-date inventory of data can help the FCO to: 

  • inform people about what types of data they can access from the FCO
  • manage and organise your data assets
  • comply with new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requirements around maintaining records of personal data and processing activities

body: Not all data should be published openly, especially where it contains sensitive data. Which of the following are justifications to keep data closed?
title: Q: Dealing with sensitive data
instruction: Select three answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Releasing data will endanger lives
Releasing data will damage the UK's competitive advantage
Releasing data will affect an ongoing criminal court case
Releasing data will negatively impact the government
The data will not be of interest to the public

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Justifications to keep data closed may be made on the grounds of national security, privacy and confidentiality, commercially or market sensitive data, intellectual property and ongoing investigations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Justifications to keep data closed may be made on the grounds of national security, privacy and confidentiality, commercially or market sensitive data, intellectual property and ongoing investigations.

body: How does transparency relate to open government?
displayTitle: The pillars of an open government
title: Q: The pillars of an open government
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: Transparency is one of the four pillars
Transparency is the main agenda in an open government
Transparency is not part of open government

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

There are four pillars of open government - transparency, participation, anti-corruption and technical innovation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

There are four pillars of open government - transparency, participation, anti-corruption and technical innovation.

body: Data is different from information because...
title: Q: Data as a raw material
instruction: Select your answer and click 'Submit'

_items.text: data is raw and can be turned into lots of different types of information
data is static and only relevant at one point in time
information is shared publicly while data should remain closed

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data is a raw material that has not been processed for use. A distinction is sometimes made between data and information to the effect that information is the end product of data processing. Unprocessed data can be turned into lots of different types of information, but the reverse is not possible.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data is a raw material that has not been processed for use. A distinction is sometimes made between data and information to the effect that information is the end product of data processing. Unprocessed data can be turned into lots of different types of information, but the reverse is not possible.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as a representative of the UK overseas, plays a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government. 

Open data helps FCO to:
displayTitle: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments
title: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments

_items.title: Raise global standards
_items.body:
In this era of digital diplomacy, open data helps the FCO to raise global standards so that more information is available - for example through implementation of the Extractives Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). 

The EITI promotes transparency and better management of all steps along the value chain within the oil, gas and mining industries. This includes contracts and licensing, production, revenue collection, revenue allocation, and social and economic spending.

_items.title: Make all government data more open and transparent
_items.body:
The FCO plays an important role in supporting the capacity of governments to become more open and transparent. 

For example, the UK Embassy in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) is working with a range of partners to strengthen the capacity for implementing open data in BiH, even within a constrained political environment.

Projects include producing an ‘open government’ guide for government and civil society representatives, supporting an open government working group leading advocacy efforts for BiH to join the OGP, and training civil servants from key Ministries to format and publish open data.

_items.title: Increase transparency in UK aid flows
_items.body:
This allows people in developing countries to hold their governments to account for spending the aid effectively, while those people who give generously in the UK can see the impact their money makes.

For example, follow the money in Nigeria visualises and tracks government spending and international aid, and communicates aid effectiveness back to rural communities.

The International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) aims to improve the transparency of aid, development, and humanitarian resources and to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation activities.

body: -- Francis Maude, 2012
displayTitle: Data is 'the new raw material of the 21st century'
title: Data is 'the new raw material of the 21st century'

body:
Raw data (sometimes called source data or atomic data) is data that has not been processed for use.

A distinction is sometimes made between data and information to the effect that information is the end product of data processing. For example, data such as location coordinates, images, descriptions and maps feed into a dataset which can be used to provide information about FCO offices around the world.

Raw open data allows anyone to use and analyse the data at any point, whereas information only provides a snapshot at a point in time.

Think of data like the raw food ingredients and information like a 'ready meal': both have their place but one is much more flexible than the other!
title: Data as a raw material

body:
Data plays an important role within a modern diplomatic service.  It is important for knowledge management, generating insights and intelligence, designing better public-facing services (eg up to date travel advice), ensuring proper resourcing, and informing better decisions.

Enabled by new technology, FCO staff are able to access and use different data sources – including social media, big data and open data – to help with decision making. Digital technology is also shaping the way states interact, with ‘digital diplomacy’ working alongside traditional face-to-face diplomacy to help achieve diplomatic objectives, as described here by former UK Ambassador, Tom Fletcher [video]. Read more about the FCO’s commitments to digital transformation in the Future FCO report.
displayTitle: The benefits of data in the FCO
title: The benefits of data in the FCO
instruction: Find out more about the important role of raw data in the FCO below:

_items.title: Crisis management
_items.body:
Publishing and making use of open data in crises response can ensure a faster and more effective response.

Data is a critical resource when responding to natural or manmade crises. In emergency situations or in resource-constrained environments, having access to raw data is essential to help pinpoint areas of need.

Open data plays a key role in crisis response as it provides a source of data that everyone can access and use.

In particular, the OpenStreetMap community is often at the heart of humanitarian response situations, for example, in response to devastating earthquakes in Nepal or Haiti. 

Open data can also help facilitate information flows between humanitarian actors, service providers and government agencies. For example, open data played a key role during Ebola outbreak to strengthen service delivery, monitoring risk and assessing needs.

_items.title: Consular services
_items.body:
The delivery of consular services is complex and multi-faceted. Collecting and using data more effectively can help evaluate the performance and cost of providing such services and identify potential ways to improve. 

The FCO already holds (and publishes) key consular performance statistics. 

Consular data ranks highly in Freedom of Information (FOI) requests to the FCO. A more proactive publication scheme, such as the provision of open data, would reduce the burden of answering such requests and potentially reduce the number of requests.

In South Australia, release of open data led to a 31% reduction in FOI requests.

_items.title: Diplomacy and trade
_items.body:
There is growing evidence that open data contributes to economic growth and trade by:

Opening up procurement data to help more small businesses compete for opportunities:

Spend Network provides insight and analysis on public procurement and finance data to help suppliers identify opportunities to bid for government grants.

Improving trade connections between countries

Labora is an open data accelerator in Mexico – linking entrepreneurs working with open data to mentors, investors and data providers/regulators. With support of the UK Embassy and the Open Data Institute, the project has also facilitated exchanges between startups in the UK and Mexico.

Helping businesses to comply with local and international regulations

Better Regulation Delivery Office (Ukraine) uses open data to provide quick-access to a ‘rolling review’ of regulation information to help businesses navigate relevant regulations.

body: The FCO manages a lot of data and has committed to data being 'open by default'. But not all data should be made open. It is important for you to recognise what data can be made open and what data cannot. In this section, we explore principles which can help you make decisions around data sharing.
displayTitle: Supporting the FCO Open Data Strategy
title: Supporting the FCO Open Data Strategy

_items.title: Knowing the FCO commitments
_items.body:
The FCO has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and an Open Data Strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets which should be available openly.

The datasets list is regularly reviewed and added to. If a particular dataset is not listed, you should consider if the dataset could be open in accordance with the principles of ‘open by default’ (publish data for all to use unless there is a good reason not to).

_items.title: Knowing what data you have
_items.body:
When an organisation manages large volumes of data, it can be helpful to maintain a data inventory. Data inventories provide a full list of data assets collected and maintained by an organisation (whether they are open, shared, or closed). Maintaining and publishing a data inventory helps to:

  • Inform people about what types of data they can access from the FCO
  • Manage and organise your data assets
  • Comply with new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requirements around maintaining records of personal data and processing activities

As an example, HM Land Registry provides an open Dataset Inventory of all the electronic data held by Land Registry, including both internal (closed) and external (open) raw data.

_items.title: Knowing how widely the data can be shared
_items.body:
When deciding whether a dataset can be shared or made open it can be helpful to map the datasets that you have on the Open Data Institute's ‘Data Spectrum’.

The Data Spectrum categorises data into open/shared/closed based on who can be granted access to the dataset, and how they are permitted to use the data.

You can find out more about using The Data Spectrum in this article.

_items.title: Knowing how to move towards open
_items.body:
Some data can be made open without requiring changes. Other data might need to be changed before it can be published to ensure it doesn't contain sensitive data.

Such data might include:

  • National security data
  • Personal data
  • Commercially sensitive data 
  • Data that the FCO does not have the right to publish
  • Data related to current investigations

You can explore each of these in more detail in the next part of the module.

body:
Not all data should be made open, especially where it contains sensitive data. If not treated sensitively, it can affect people's trust in data and in the responsible organisation.

There are legitimate reasons why some FCO data should not be published openly. Justifications may be made on the grounds of:
title: Dealing with sensitive data

_items.title: National security
_items.body:
Transparency sometimes needs to be balanced against national security issues. There may be good reason not to disclose information such as defence or security assets, or location and timing of counter-terrorism exercises, which could damage capabilities or effectiveness of UK operations.

For example, publishing diplomatic telegrams which contain intelligence regarding an unfolding political coup or sensitive policy advice could put operations or people at risk.

_items.title: Privacy and confidentiality
_items.body:
Data containing personally identifiable information (PII) should not be released widely to protect individuals.

However data can be published if the data has been suitably anonymised in accordance with privacy legislation and internationally recognised standards.

For example consular reports containing data about the location of pickpocketing and theft incidents reported at airports might contain PII. However, if the data is anonymised, it could be useful to understand spikes in petty crime activity in different areas.

You can find out more about anonymisation in this online guide, or by getting in touch with the UK Anonymisation Network (UKAN).

_items.title: Commercially or market sensitive data
_items.body:
Commercially or market-sensitive data may be damaging to the UK government or to a commercial partner if improperly accessed. Much commercial data may be time sensitive, with the potential harm caused by disclosure diminishing over time. For example, the sensitivity of data relating to interest rates is likely to diminish in this way as time passes.

Data on future transactions regarding dealings in the extractives industry are widely regarded as commercially sensitive as disclosure to the public could cause actual harm.

_items.title: Intellectual property
_items.body:
Publishing data which is protected by copyright or database rights may not be permitted under law. It is important to determine what intellectual property rights exist in the data before you consider opening it and publishing under an open licence.

For example, sharing and re-use of Flickr photos of FCO embassy events may be prohibited if they have not been published under an open licence.

_graphic.attribution: Photoroyalty - Freepik.com [CC-BY]

_items.title: Investigations
_items.body:
Data from investigations or civil or criminal proceedings could compromise public protection or enforcement activities, or prejudice court cases.

For example publishing the identity of persons being investigated for war crimes might put family members at risk.

body:
A standard is an agreed way of doing something. It is critical to ensuring one thing is compatible with another, no matter where in the world it is. Standards mean that trains can travel on different lines around the country, planes can be refuelled at any airport and DVDs read on any DVD player.

Standards for data help us to publish and use data in ways that are consistent and easy to access. They help to make data comparable and interoperable with other data that uses the same standards.

Data published to a standard will have the same heading fields. The data is likely to have been collected or processed in the same way, as the standard dictates.
displayTitle: The role of standards in increasing quality
title: The role of standards in increasing quality

_items.title: Introduction to the IATI standard
_items.body:
The FCO is committed to publishing its data to the International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) standard. 

The IATI standard is a technical publishing framework allowing data to be easily compared.

Over 600 organisations interested in aid and transparency have published data to the IATI standard. This includes national and international non-governmental organisations, governments, academic organisations and even some private sector organisations. In the UK, the FCO, Defra, DFID, MOD and DWP all publish data to the IATI standard.

_items.title: The principles of the IATI standard
_items.body:
The principles of the IATI standard are similar to the Open Data Charter. Data should be:

  • Timely
  • Comprehensive
  • Forward looking
  • Structured
  • Comparable 
  • Open
_items.strapline: The principles of the IATI standard

_items.title: IATI: two levels
_items.body:
The IATI Standard requires publication of data about both the organisation and development cooperation activities carried out by the organisation:

  • The Organisation Standard is used to describe an organisation involved in any stage development cooperation (funding, implementing etc.).
  • The Activity Standard is used to describe the details of individual development cooperation activities/projects.

_items.title: Publishing to the IATI standard
_items.body:
IATI has a central registry where you can access all data published to the IATI standard.

Much like data.gov.uk, the IATI registry contains links to datasets published openly on the web that conform to the IATI standard. 

Within the FCO the Transparency Unit manages this as part of the publication process.

Find out more about publishing to the IATI standard here or contact the transparency unit directly.

body: Why is it important to describe an open data publication?
title: Q: Steps to publishing open data
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: To provide context and make it more comprehensive and usable
To show your boss how well you've done your work
Because it says so on this page

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

You should provide a description alongside open data to provide context and to make it more comprehensive and usable. A description can also help others to discover the open data either via a web search engine or through a portal such as data.gov.uk

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You should provide a description alongside open data to provide context and to make it more comprehensive and usable. A description can also help others to discover the open data either via a web search engine or through a portal such as data.gov.uk

displayTitle: Are you ready to maximise the benefit of data at the FCO?
title: Are you ready to maximise the benefit of data at the FCO?

displayTitle: Are you ready to lead in transparency and openness?
title: Are you ready to lead in transparency and openness?

body:
While transparency is a key pillar in an open government it is not the only area where open data can play a key role.

While current practices take a 'closed by default' approach, an 'open by default' approach would not only aid transparency but also provide benefits to the other pillars of an open government. 

The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as a representative of the UK overseas, play a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government and helping lead the way. 

Next module
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
Publishing sustainable open data helps to improve the reputation of the publisher as a reliable provider of timely, usable and interoperable open data.

Sustainability is important for an organisation that is committed to being 'open by default'. It is not enough to publish open data once, publishers need to be committed to releasing regular or frequent updates.

In this module we'll explore:

  • The steps to publishing open data
  • Why does licensing matter?
  • Making open data more sustainable
  • Embedding sustainability in your organisation
title: Publishing sustainable open data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
Without a licence, data is not truly open.

An open licence means that anyone can access, use and share the data.

Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available’, but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

The UK government uses the Open Government Licence (OGL).

The OGL is a simple, clear licence designed to promote the broadest possible reuse of public data, while protecting the rights of the publisher.

Each dataset on the UK government open data portal displays the licence directly under the dataset title at the top of the page. This makes the licence very easy to find while also being clear that the licence relates directly to the dataset shown.

Placing this licence on your dataset takes only a few minutes. To apply your licence, go to the OGL page.
title: Why does licensing matter?

displayTitle: Are you ready to publish sustainable open data?
title: Are you ready to publish sustainable open data?

body:
Without timely, reliable and quality data, we can't inform decisions, provide evidence for statements or build new products and services.

Data quality can improved in a number of way: from cleaning data to reduce errors, to using a standard to make data more interoperable.

In this module we will explore:

  • Recognising errors in data
  • Reducing errors from data
  • Comparable and interoperable data
  • The role of standards in increasing quality
  • Recognising quality
title: Improving data quality

displayTitle: Are you ready to publish quality data?
title: Are you ready to publish quality data?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

body:
A key part of sustainable open data publication, is for open data practice to be embedded in the day-to-day business of your organisation.

For this to happen, everyone in the organisation needs to be on board with the concept of open data. Although difficult to achieve, below we explore some of the key elements that will help to embed sustainable open data practices in your organisation.
displayTitle: Embedding open data in your organisation
title: Embedding open data in your organisation

_items.title: Clear vision
_items.body:
A clear vision about the use of open data can help ensure its sustainability within an organisation. Without a clear vision, it is difficult to ensure support, either internally or externally.

This vision needs to be understandable, jargon-free and in alignment with the organisation's strategic objectives and values.

This vision should outline aspects such as making data 'open by default', where and how data is sourced, and how it will be licensed.

_items.title: Strong leadership
_items.body:
Strong endorsement and leadership by senior staff can help to embed open data practice into an organisation's day-to-day business.

It doesn't need to be the most senior people in the organisation, but they do need to have decision-making responsibilities.

Their role is to inspire the organisation to embrace open data, reassure those who are fearful or reluctant, and provide the budget, time and skills (either through upskilling the team or hiring new people) to ensure that open data remains high on the priority list.

_items.title: Buy-in at all levels
_items.body:
The entire organisation needs to be signed up to the concept of open data and 'open by default' for it to be successfully embedded.

Internal staff need to be upskilled on what open data is, what 'open by default' means, why both are important, and crucially what 'open' and 'data' mean for them in their daily roles.

People are often reluctant to change their ways of working. Leaders should consider and listen to their concerns, and the reasons why they might be reticent or anxious to use or publish open data.

_items.title: Active engagement
_items.body:
Engagement with civil society, business and government are key aspects of any open data initiative.

Successful initiatives tend to start with an open dialogue between open data publishers and consumers.

This dialogue is important for both parties to understand the demand for data and opportunities to draw out its benefits.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
Publishing sustainable open data helps to improve the reputation of the publisher as a reliable provider of timely, usable and interoperable open data.

You can reassure users that open data is sustainable by including an open licence, which explains that anyone can access, use and share the data.

Reinforce the FCO’s reputation as a reliable provider of timely, usable and interoperable open data by providing: the data source; the publishing history; a timeline for expected updates; information about existing users and contributing communities; as well as anything that demonstrates commitment to open data.

Having a clear vision and strong leadership will help to get support for open data publishing, both internally and externally. This in turn will help to embed publishing sustainable open data into the day-to-day business of the FCO.

Next module
title: Summary

body:
Another way to improve the quality of data is to make it more comparable and interoperable with other data. Data is at its most valuable when it is combined with other data. Making data comparable and interoperable data is the fourth principle of the Open Data Charter.

Data can be more comparable and interoperable when it is presented in structured and standardised formats. Users should have access to sufficient information to understand the source, strengths, weaknesses and analytical limitations of the data. To help with this, data should be fully described with all accompanying documentation written in clear, plain language.

A data standard can help with this as it details exactly how data should be structured, described and published. This means that it is easier to compare data. We explore data standards more in the next block.
title: Making data comparable and interoperable

body: The FCO has committed to being ‘open by default’, the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed. In this next section, we explore how to publish FCO data to help fulfil that mandate.
title: Steps to publishing open data
instruction: Click on the headings to explore more

_items.title: Prioritise which data you want to publish
_items.body:
In an ‘open by default’ organisation, data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed.

However there may be some data which should be prioritised for publication, if, for example, it will be useful to your organisation or aligns closely with your open data strategy.

For example, the FCO publishes statistics on consular services provided to British nationals worldwide. This is done on a regular monthly basis as outlined in the FCO Open Data Policy.

Another example is the Irish government's Open Data Strategy that prioritises publishing high economic value datasets.

_items.title: Prepare the data
_items.body:
Before open data can be published, it needs to be prepared. Structuring, organising and cleaning data helps to make it more comprehensive and usable, both internally and externally.

It is estimated that 80% of the time spend on any data project is on preparing the data. 

In the next module, we explore how to ensure the quality of open data.

_items.title: Redact the data
_items.body:
Once the data is prepared, you might need to redact any entries that are exempt from publication. This might be for reasons of national security, third party rights, privacy and confidentiality or commercial sensitivity.

Data should still be comprehensive. If you anonymise or aggregate data to remove personal or sensitive data, this should be done in such a way as to preserve as much value of releasing the dataset as possible. 

The latest advice and guidance on redacting data at the FCO can be obtained by contacting the Transparency Unit.

_items.title: Describe the data
_items.body:
Good quality data has a description that can help anyone understand and interpret that data. This is often referred to as descriptive metadata (data about data).

Metadata can help provide context for a dataset and make it more comprehensive and usable. For example, it might be useful to outline how the data was collected, or any limitations on the data. You might even explain anomalies in the data where appropriate.

Metadata can also help facilitate the discovery of open data. Adding data about genre or other classification can help others discover other similar datasets. On the web, metadata helps search engines find content from across the web.

Metadata isn't just useful for external users. It can also help an organisation to discover, understand and interpret data that it holds.

_items.title: License the data
_items.body:
Open data is not open unless it has a licence stating that anyone can access, use or share it.

The FCO is mandated to use the Open Government Licence (OGL) for all open data publications.

The next block of this module provides guidance on licensing your data.

_items.title: Publish the data
_items.body:
Links to data should be provided on portals and relevant websites that give people confidence that they are accessing authoritative data. 

UK government departments should publish or upload open data to their organisation's website.

The Transparency Unit manages the process of adding datasets to data.gov.uk following the Data.gov.uk guidance. Any publication queries should be directed to the Transparency Unit.

Once the dataset is published, check it is live, can be downloaded by anyone and displays correctly after download.

_items.title: Promote the data
_items.body: The final step is to promote your release. Write a blog or press release to let people know, and promote the new data on social media. If you are aware of any open data user communities, get in touch with them and invite them to try out the new data. Make sure that you promote internally as well as externally, as people within your organisation are the most likely users.

body: What role does open data play within an Open Government?
displayTitle: The role of open data in an Open Government
title: Q: The role of open data in an Open Government
instruction: Select your answer and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Open data is just part of the 'transparency' pillar
Open data is at the heart of all pillars in an open government
Open data helps evaluate the success of the open government partnership

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open data is at the heart of all four of the pillars of open government.

Open data can support transparency by reducing the number of FOI requests and streamlining the response to others. 

Open data can support citizen participation by allowing citizens to see inside the workings of government, monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account and participate in decision-making.

Open data can support anti-corruption through publishing data on who controls and benefits from companies and procurement.

Open data can help technological innovation by delivering new services to the public while driving efficiencies in the delivery of current public services.

_incorrect.final:
That's right!

Open data is at the heart of all four of the pillars of open government.

Open data can support transparency by reducing the number of FOI requests and streamlining the response to others. 

Open data can support citizen participation by allowing citizens to see inside the workings of government, monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account and participate in decision-making.

Open data can support anti-corruption through publishing data on who controls and benefits from companies and procurement.

Open data can help technological innovation by delivering new services to the public while driving efficiencies in the delivery of current public services.

body: You have been tasked to collect a new set of data, how do you decide whether it should be available as open data?
displayTitle: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda
title: Q: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: You establish the demand for it from users
You submit a case for it being open to the open data project
There is no need to, it should be open by default. A case should have to be made to close it

_feedback.correct:
That's right

'Open by default' is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

'Open by default' is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed.

body: Without clean data, we can’t build information. There are a number of useful tools that can help when cleaning data.
title: Reducing errors from data
instruction: Click on the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: The data cleaning toolkit
_items.body:
When you are looking for errors in data, it may be necessary to download and upload datasets and to use tools for cleaning and processing.

It is also important to keep a note of what changes have been made and share these openly with others so that everyone can benefit from your work, particularly if the data you are cleaning is existing open data that has been published.

_items.title: Open Refine
_items.body:
Open Refine is a software tool designed to deal with uncleaned data. The tool is a column-based browser that allows you to fix errors across an entire open dataset in a single action. The errors that can be fixed include:

  • Date formats
  • Multiple representations
  • Duplicate records
  • Redundant data
  • Mixed numerical scales
  • Mixed ranges

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in Open Refine

_items.title: Spreadsheet programmes
_items.body:
Open Refine is a key tool for cleaning data. However, it is sometimes easier to fix some errors in a spreadsheet programme:

  • Spelling errors
  • Redundant data
  • Numerical verification
  • Fixing shifted data

body:
Sustainable open data is important for an organisation that is committed to being 'open by default'.

Sustainable open data is supported by:

  • Secure funding to cover the cost of updates
  • Active support of publishers to prioritise updates
  • Wide reuse by others to demonstrate the value

Below, we explore some information that you could provide alongside the data to reassure both internal and external users that your publication is sustainable.
title: Making open data more sustainable
instruction: Click the forward arrow to explore more

_items.title: The source
_items.body:
One of the first questions a user will ask is: 'who has released the data?'. An important indicator of sustainability is how confident users feel in the organisation that collects and publishes data.

To reassure your users, you can include links to the FCO's commitment and mandate to publish open data.

Users may also be concerned that elections or changes in government policy may affect the release of the data, or if the data is tied to a specific project.

This should all be made clear in the description of the data.

_items.title: The publishing history
_items.body:
The perceived quality and viability of open data to a large extent depends on the trust placed in its publisher.

Users will look at when a dataset was first published, as well as how regularly the updates are made.

A long history of updates is a good sign, but users will be aware of external factors such as project length or term in office. A key indicator of a sustainable initiative is one that outlives these external factors.

When publishing open data, you should include an expected update date in your description of the data.

_items.title: Existing users
_items.body:
The more widely a dataset is used, the more pressure there is for it to be sustained.

Users can be internal or external. In fact, one of the most frequent re-users of open data is often the publisher themselves. This is especially true with large organisations with multiple departments, agencies and external bodies, such as the FCO.

Demonstrating that the data is already being used internally will reassure other internal and external users that the publishing organisation cares about the dataset and is unlikely to remove access to it.

_items.title: Contributing communities
_items.body:
Datasets are most sustainable when they are being used.

Are there any communities of practice that exist around the dataset? What kind of role could the FCO play with these communities?

Encouraging feedback on the data, and demonstrating that you are acting on that feedback, will also provide reassurance that the data is sustainable.

body: What are the key elements of embedding open data in your organisation?
displayTitle: Embedding open data in your organisation
title: Q: Embedding open data in your organisation
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: Working from the top down, mandating change and implementing it quickly
Having clear vision and leadership, spending time getting buy in from the team and engaging with external users
Using the right terminology, working from the ground up and introducing change quickly

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Having clear vision and leadership, spending time getting buy in from the team and engaging with external users will help to embed sustainable open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Having clear vision and leadership, spending time getting buy in from the team and engaging with external users will help to embed sustainable open data.

body: The FCO is committed to publishing data to the IATI standard. Where do you publish IATI data?
title: Q: The role of standards
instruction: Select your answer and click 'Submit'

_items.text: You publish the data to IATI's registry
You publish the data to your own site and include a link on IATI's registry
You don't have to do anything, as it is automatically published

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

You publish data on your own site and then copy the publicly accessible URL to the IATI central registry. This means that the data is updated from your own site, and is available in both places. This gives you maximum control, whilst the data is more likely to be seen by more people.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You publish data on your own site and then copy the publicly accessible URL to the IATI central registry. This means that the data is updated from your own site, and is available in both places. This gives you maximum control, whilst the data is more likely to be seen by more people.

body:
Without timely, reliable and quality data, we can't inform decisions, provide evidence for statements or build new products and services. Data quality can improved in a number of ways.

In this module we have explored how to recognise and reduce errors by cleaning data, how to make data more interoperable by using a standard and how to recognise a quality marque for data.

The FCO is committed to publishing high quality data to the IATI standard. You can find out more about the IATI standard on the IATI website including detailed guidance on how to publish data.
title: Summary

body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.
title: Recognising errors in data
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Wrong formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Microsoft Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in spelling, capitalisation and spacing can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body: Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800,000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, which causes errors.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: To enable a machine to understand these ranges it is important that the ranges are consistent across the dataset, ie not using both 18–29 and 25–34 as age ranges.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

body: What are two of the most useful tools for cleaning data?
title: Q: Reducing errors in data
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: Microsoft Access and Adobe Photoshop
Apple Notes and Microsoft Word
Open Refine and Microsoft Excel

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open Refine and Microsoft Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open Refine and Microsoft Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning open data.

body: How does a data standard make data more comparable and interoperable?
title: Q: Making data comparable and interoperable
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: A data standard details how data should be structured, described and published
A data standard is a tick box exercise
A data standard means that you don't have to clean your data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A data standard can help make data more comparable and interoperable as it details exactly how data should be structured, described and published.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

A data standard can help make data more comparable and interoperable as it details exactly how data should be structured, described and published.

body: The FCO plays a key role in supporting open governments both in the UK and overseas by ...
displayTitle: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments both in the UK and overseas
title: Q: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments both in the UK and overseas
instruction: Select all correct answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Raising global standards so that more information is available
Making all government data 'open by default'
Increasing transparency of our work
Publishing employee records
Creating a data economy

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The FCO plays a key role in supporting open governments both in the UK and overseas by raising global standards so that more information is available, making all government data 'open by default' and increasing transparency of our work.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The FCO plays a key role in supporting open governments both in the UK and overseas by raising global standards so that more information is available, making all government data 'open by default' and increasing transparency of our work.

body: Open data can help boost diplomacy and trade by...
displayTitle: The benefits of data in the FCO
title: Q: The benefits of data in the FCO
instruction: Select three answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Helping suppliers identify opportunities to bid for government grants
Linking entrepreneurs working with open data to mentors, investors, data providers/regulators in different countries
Improving the regulation and delivery of services
Helping hold governments to account
Being a raw material which we can trade with other countries

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open data can help boost trade and diplomacy by opening up procurement data to help more small businesses compete for opportunities, improving trade connections between countries and help businesses to comply with local and international regulations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data can help boost trade and diplomacy by opening up procurement data to help more small businesses compete for opportunities, improving trade connections between countries and help businesses to comply with local and international regulations.

body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?
title: Q: Recognising errors in data
instruction: Choose three answers and click submit

_items.text: Lack of licence
Redundant data
Mixed numerical scales
Lack of granularity
Multiple representations

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

body: An open licence tells users that:
title: Q: Why does licensing matter?
instruction: Select your answer and click submit

_items.text: they can access, use and share the data
they can't make money from the data
they must contact the publisher if they wish to change the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

An open licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share the data. Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available’, but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

Anyone can reuse open data for commercial purposes. This is written explicitly in the Open Government Licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An open licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share the data. Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available’, but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

Anyone can reuse open data for commercial purposes. This is written explicitly in the Open Government Licence.

body: The Open Data Institute advocates the use of its own quality marque known as...
title: Q: Recognising quality
instruction: Select all correct answers and click submit

_items.text: the ODI stamp of approval
Open Data Certificates
the ODI big green tick

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

body: Which of the following are a sign of sustainability?
title: Q: Making open data more sustainable
instruction: Select three answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: A date when the data is expected to be updated
A history of regular updates at set intervals
Examples of how others are using the data
No way for people to provide feedback on the data
Long unexplained gaps between releases

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

An expected update date, a history of regular updates and examples of how others are using the data (this could be internal or external use) are signs that the data is sustainable.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An expected update date, a history of regular updates and examples of how others are using the data (this could be internal or external use) are signs that the data is sustainable.

body:
Quality marques provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.

There are two key indicators of open data quality:
title: Recognising quality
instruction: Click the headings to explore more

_items.title: 5 stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The quality marque examines the accessibility and technical usability of a dataset. Each star must be awarded sequentially and none can be skipped.

The guidelines were developed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 2001 and have been adopted by publishers worldwide to help guide many open data initiatives.

Data published on data.gov.uk is automatically awarded an openness rating based on the 5 stars.

Find out more about the openness rating on data.gov.uk

Data that is awarded three stars is often of sufficient quality.

Find out how the FCO's datasets score.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset and also provide further benefits to publishers including:

Independent mark of quality

Be recognised for your open data publication achievements with an Open Data Certificate you can display on your website.

Guide to best practice standards

Be guided through an assessment of your publication process measured against global best practices.

Free report for how to improve

Receive an easy to follow report on what is required to take you to the next level.

Engage reusers

Provide reusers with information they need to trust and rely on your data with Open Data Certificates.

Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site
